Linear Algebra.name: Determinant of a 2x2 Matrix
Linear Algebra.formula: A = \begin{bmatrix}a & b \\ c & d \end{bmatrix}, \quad det(A) = ad - bc
Linear Algebra.description: The determinant of a 2x2 matrix gives the scaling factor of the transformation represented by the matrix.

Linear Algebra.name: Inverse of a 2x2 Matrix
Linear Algebra.formula: A = \begin{bmatrix}a & b \\ c & d \end{bmatrix}, \quad A^{-1} = \frac{1}{ad - bc} \begin{vmatrix} d & -b \\ -c & a \end{vmatrix}
Linear Algebra.description: The inverse of a 2x2 matrix exists if and only if the determinant is non-zero.

Linear Algebra.name: Dot Product of Two Vectors

variables.u_i, v_i: Components of vectors u and v

Linear Algebra.description: The dot product gives a scalar that measures the projection of one vector onto another.

Linear Algebra.name: Cross Product of 3D Vectors
Linear Algebra.formula: \mathbf{u} = \begin{bmatrix} u_1 & u_2 & u_3 \end{bmatrix}, \quad \mathbf{v} = \begin{bmatrix} v_1 & v_2 & v_3 \end{bmatrix} \\,\\ \mathbf{u} \times \mathbf{v} = \begin{bmatrix} u_2 v_3 - u_3 v_2 \\ u_3 v_1 - u_1 v_3 \\ u_1 v_2 - u_2 v_1 \end{bmatrix}
Linear Algebra.description: The cross product of two 3D vectors results in a vector perpendicular to both.

Linear Algebra.name: Matrix Transpose
Linear Algebra.formula: A = \begin{bmatrix}a & b \\ c & d \end{bmatrix}, \quad (A^T) = \begin{bmatrix}a & c \\ d & d \end{bmatrix}, \quad (A^T)_{ij} = A_{ji}
Linear Algebra.description: The transpose of a matrix is formed by flipping its rows into columns.

Linear Algebra.name: Cramer's Rule for 2 Equations

variables.A_x, A_y: Matrix with replaced columns of constants

Linear Algebra.description: Cramer's rule provides a direct way of solving small linear systems using determinants.

Linear Algebra.name: Determinant of a 3x3 Matrix
Linear Algebra.formula: A = \begin{bmatrix}a & b & c \\ d & e & f \\ g & h & i \end{bmatrix}, \quad det(A) = a(ei − fh) − b(di − fg) + c(dh − eg)

variables.A: 3x3 matrix [[a, b, c], [d, e, f], [g, h, i]]

Linear Algebra.description: The determinant of a 3x3 matrix can be computed using the rule of Sarrus or cofactor expansion.

Linear Algebra.name: Trace of a Matrix
Linear Algebra.description: The trace of a matrix is the sum of its diagonal elements and is invariant under similarity transformations.

Linear Algebra.name: Scalar Multiplication of a Matrix
Linear Algebra.description: Scalar multiplication scales every entry of the matrix by the given scalar.

Linear Algebra.name: Matrix Addition

variables.a_{ij}, b_{ij}: Corresponding elements of A and B

Linear Algebra.description: Two matrices of the same dimension can be added element by element.

Linear Algebra.name: Matrix Multiplication
Linear Algebra.description: Matrix multiplication combines rows of the first matrix with columns of the second. It is not commutative in general.

Linear Algebra.name: Rank of a Matrix
Linear Algebra.formula: rank(A) = \text{dimension of the column space of } A
Linear Algebra.description: The rank of a matrix is the maximum number of linearly independent columns (or rows).

Linear Algebra.name: Norm of a Vector
Linear Algebra.description: The Euclidean norm measures the length (magnitude) of a vector.

Linear Algebra.name: Unit Vector
Linear Algebra.description: A unit vector points in the same direction as v but has magnitude 1.

Linear Algebra.name: Projection of u onto v

variables.u · v: Dot product of u and v

Linear Algebra.description: The projection of u onto v gives the component of u in the direction of v.

Linear Algebra.name: Orthogonality Condition
Linear Algebra.description: Two vectors are orthogonal if their dot product equals zero.

Linear Algebra.name: Determinant of a Triangular Matrix
Linear Algebra.description: A triangular matrix is a special type of square matrix where all the entries either above or below the main diagonal are zero. The determinant of a triangular matrix is the product of its diagonal elements.

Linear Algebra.name: Characteristic Polynomial
Linear Algebra.description: The characteristic polynomial is used to compute the eigenvalues of a matrix.

Linear Algebra.name: Eigenvalue Equation
Linear Algebra.description: An eigenvalue λ of A is a scalar such that Av = λv for some nonzero vector v.

Linear Algebra.name: Eigenvector Normalization
Linear Algebra.description: Eigenvectors are often normalized to have unit length.

Linear Algebra.name: Inverse of a 2x2 Matrix
Linear Algebra.formula: A = \begin{bmatrix}a & b \\ c & d \end{bmatrix} \\ \ \\ A^{-1} = \frac{1}{ad - bc} \begin{bmatrix} d & -b \\ -c & a \end{bmatrix}
Linear Algebra.description: The inverse of a 2x2 matrix exists if its determinant is nonzero.

Linear Algebra.name: Cofactor Expansion (Laplace Expansion)
Linear Algebra.description: The determinant can be computed by expanding along any row or column.

Linear Algebra.name: Principle of Mathematical Induction
Linear Algebra.formula: \text{If } P(1) \text{ is true and } P(k) \implies P(k+1) \text{ for all } k \in \mathbb{N}, \text{ then } P(n) \text{ is true } \forall n \in \mathbb{N}
Linear Algebra.description: The principle of mathematical induction is a proof technique used to establish that a statement is true for all natural numbers.

Linear Algebra.name: Complex Number in Polar Form
Linear Algebra.formula: z = r (cos θ + i sin θ)
Linear Algebra.description: A complex number can be represented in polar form using its modulus and argument.

Linear Algebra.name: Multiplication of Complex Numbers in Polar Form
Linear Algebra.description: To multiply complex numbers in polar form, multiply their moduli and add their arguments.

Linear Algebra.name: Division of Complex Numbers in Polar Form
Linear Algebra.description: To divide complex numbers in polar form, divide their moduli and subtract their arguments.

Linear Algebra.name: De Moivre's Theorem
Linear Algebra.description: De Moivre's theorem relates powers of complex numbers in polar form to multiple-angle trigonometric identities.

Linear Algebra.name: nth Roots of Complex Numbers
Linear Algebra.description: The nth roots of a complex number are evenly spaced points on a circle in the complex plane.

Linear Algebra.name: Roots of Unity
Linear Algebra.description: The nth roots of unity are the complex solutions of z^n = 1.

Linear Algebra.name: Logarithm of a Complex Number
Linear Algebra.description: The logarithm of a complex number is multivalued, differing by integer multiples of 2πi.

Linear Algebra.name: Expansion of sin(nθ)
Linear Algebra.description: Using De Moivre's theorem, \sin(n\theta) can be expanded into powers of \sin and \cos.

Linear Algebra.name: Expansion of cos(nθ)
Linear Algebra.description: Using De Moivre's theorem, \cos(n\theta) can be expanded into powers of \sin and \cos.

Linear Algebra.name: Trigonometric Identities (Pythagorean)
Linear Algebra.description: One of the fundamental trigonometric identities relating sine and cosine.

Linear Algebra.name: Vector Addition
Linear Algebra.description: The sum of two vectors is obtained by adding corresponding components.

Linear Algebra.name: Dot Product of Two Vectors
Linear Algebra.formula: \vec{u} \cdot \vec{v} = |\vec{u}||\vec{v}|\cos\theta = u_1 v_1 + u_2 v_2 + u_3 v_3
Linear Algebra.description: The dot product gives a scalar and relates to the cosine of the angle between vectors.

Linear Algebra.name: Scalar Projection of a Vector
Linear Algebra.description: The scalar projection is the length of \vec{v} projected onto \vec{u}.

Linear Algebra.name: Vector Projection of a Vector
Linear Algebra.description: The vector projection gives a vector along \vec{u} representing the projection of \vec{v}.

Linear Algebra.name: Scalar Triple Product
Linear Algebra.description: The scalar triple product gives the volume of the parallelepiped formed by three vectors.

Linear Algebra.name: Linear Dependence of Vectors
Linear Algebra.description: Vectors are linearly dependent if a non-trivial linear combination of them gives the zero vector.

Linear Algebra.name: Parametric Equations of a Line in 3D
Linear Algebra.formula: x = x_0 + at, \ y = y_0 + bt, \ z = z_0 + ct
Linear Algebra.description: The parametric form of a line in 3D expresses coordinates in terms of a parameter t.

example.problem: \text{Find parametric equations of line through } (1, 2, 3) \text{ with direction } (2, 1, -1).

Linear Algebra.name: Symmetric Equations of a Line in 3D
Linear Algebra.description: The symmetric form eliminates the parameter from the parametric form of the line.

example.problem: \text{Find symmetric form of line through } (1, 2, 3) \text{ with direction } (2, 1, -1).

Linear Algebra.name: Gaussian Elimination (Row Echelon Form)
Linear Algebra.formula: \text{Use elementary row operations to reduce } A \text{ to upper triangular form.}
Linear Algebra.description: Gaussian elimination transforms a system of equations into row echelon form to solve linear systems.

Linear Algebra.name: Row Echelon Form (REF)
Linear Algebra.formula: \text{A matrix is in REF if:} \\ 1. \text{ All nonzero rows are above any zero rows. } \\ 2. \text{ The leading entry of each nonzero row is to the right of the leading entry of the row above. } \\ 3. \text{ All entries below a leading entry are zero. }

variables.Leading entry: First nonzero entry in a row
variables.Row: Horizontal line of entries in the matrix

Linear Algebra.description: REF is a simplified form of a matrix obtained by Gaussian elimination, useful for solving systems of linear equations.

example.solution: \text{Yes. The leading entries (1, 3, 5) shift rightward as rows progress, and zeros lie below each pivot.}

Linear Algebra.name: Reduced Row Echelon Form (RREF)
Linear Algebra.formula: \text{A matrix is in RREF if it is in REF and:} \\ 4. \text{ Each leading entry is } 1. \\ 5. \text{ Each leading 1 is the only nonzero entry in its column. }
Linear Algebra.description: RREF is the fully reduced version of REF, obtained by Gauss-Jordan elimination.

example.solution: \text{Divide each pivot row by its leading coefficient and eliminate above pivots: } \\ \begin{bmatrix}1 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1\end{bmatrix}.

Linear Algebra.name: Gauss-Jordan Elimination
Linear Algebra.formula: 1. \text{ Use row operations to reach REF. } \\ 2. \text{ Scale each pivot to 1. } \\ 3. \text{ Eliminate entries above each pivot to reach RREF. }

variables.Row operations: Swapping rows, scaling rows, adding multiples of rows

Linear Algebra.description: Gauss-Jordan elimination is a method to solve linear systems, invert matrices, and compute RREF.

example.problem: \text{Solve the system } x + y = 2, \ x - y = 0 \text{ using Gauss-Jordan elimination.}

Linear Algebra.name: Vector Cross Product
Linear Algebra.description: The cross product of two vectors in 3D gives a vector perpendicular to both, with magnitude |a||b|sin(θ).

Linear Algebra.name: Rank-Nullity Theorem

variables.\\text{rank}(A): Dimension of the column space of A
variables.\\text{nullity}(A): Dimension of the null space of A

Linear Algebra.description: The theorem relates the rank and nullity of a matrix, ensuring the sum equals the number of variables in the system.

example.solution: \text{rank}(A)=2 \ (\text{two pivots}), \ \text{nullity}=1 \ (\text{one free variable}). \\ \text{Rank + nullity = 3 = number of columns.}
